metadata.h1: Jupyter deployment models from local to production
metadata.description: Overview of a few Jupyter deployment options on the range between the simple `jupyter notebook` command and wizardry.

all_paragraphs: For nerds like us, our data analysis habits don’t stop when we close our laptops. You’ve likely had some realizations while you’re sitting in endless talks at countless conferences. For me, it was the fact that 90% of the open screens I could see from my conference seat showed a Jupyter notebook being run at http://localhost:8888.

For many of us, our notebook servers are launched simply with jupyter notebook — or jupyter notebook --allow-root --no-browser --port=8885 if we got fancy and brute-forced our way around permissions and port issues we didn’t feel like solving.
Time to science with this method is clear, but I’d like to paint a quick picture of some advanced, scalable Jupyter deployments and a few intermediate levels between jupyter notebook and wizardry.
Hopefully, you’ll get a sense of what’s possible.
(who’s reading this post and doesn’t have a Mac?)

If you’re just looking to enhance your basic Jupyter experience or you’re just looking to get started, I recommend starting here. Especially if your datasets and experiments live exclusively on your laptop.

JupyterLab is a web interface for Jupyter that allows more extensive navigation and flexibility than the traditional “tree” view you’d see if you launched vanilla Jupyter. JupyterLab lets you work in multiple tabs like a browser.
Run JupyterLab within its own conda environment directly from your mac terminal:

Prerequisite: install conda.Conda enables you to easily manage packages and environments so you can work with different combinations of libraries on your laptop (or another machine). It’s an extremely easy way to install all of the interesting, new libraries you’ll want to experiment with.

Run JupyterLab:from your Mac terminal -- Step 1: Create a new “jupyterlab” conda environment conda create -n jupyterlab ipython jupyterlab python nodejs- Step 2: Switch into that new environment source activate jupyterlab- Step 3: Start JupyterLab jupyter lab
That command will launch a browser window automatically, but every time you navigate to http://localhost:8888, you’ll get your lab UI.
The server will run until you shut it down either manually (with CTRL-C) or by closing that terminal window. Further reading about starting JupyterLab is here.
Get fancy:This great post by Jacob Tomlinson walks through how to launch JupyterLab automatically at computer startup.

Maybe you’ve heard the saying that “data science is anything that causes Excel to crash” The next stage after that is anything that doesn’t fit on a laptop. As your experiments scale, you may run into either

Either way, the solution will probably be for you to get a beefy dev server from your DevOps/IT team. That dev server will be hosted in a lab somewhere that you never physically see. You just access it remotely.
Or maybe it’s simply WFH during Covid that’s caused you to work remotely with machines that you usually work directly on.
The challenge with starting Jupyter on a remote machine is accessing the UI.
Add the --ip parameter to your jupyter launch command. It sets the IP address that the notebook server listens on (default value = “localhost”).
In your laptop browser, instead of navigating to http://localhost:8888/, you can connect directly to the server at http://<remote server IP address>:8888/ instead.
Get fancy:Are you restarting your Jupyter on your remotehost every time you open your laptop?
You can use a terminal multiplexer such as tmux or screen to essentially detach the session on your remotehost. That way, the session doesn’t depend on the connection from your localhost.
For a comparison between tmux and screen, you can check out this StackExchange post, but as the header warning states, it’s an opinion-based question.
Instructions vary per cloud vendor (see below), but the high level steps are:

Port forwarding?When you start a Jupyter server, by default, the GUI is hosted on a port on the machine where the server is launched. In this scenario, port forwarding tells your local machine to take any traffic for a specific local port and forward it to a port on a remote machine. (Further reading: The Missing Semester of Your CS Education)

If you use one of the previous deployment methods for notebooks,

What if somebody provided a reliable dev environment for you that was always available via browser and had access to shared datasets and shared notebooks? (And, as the IT team probably cares about: it’s secure and manageable across 10s or 100s of users.)
While it takes a bit more configuration–likely performed by somebody knowledgeable about your network settings–JupyterHub can be a great way to host self-service environments for an entire team.

A JuyterHub service runs constantly, providing a browser-based login for users. When a user logs in, a Jupyter server is started for them, and it connects automatically to a) their personal data from previous logins and b) any shared datasets they need to experiment with.
This deployment means that users don’t have to copy data between servers, they have a highly-available dev environment whenever they want it, and their experiments are easy to backup and share.
I’ve previously posted detailed steps for how IT teams can deploy JupyterHub in a Kubernetes environment. I’ll give a quick summary here.

JupyterHub will serve the login screen at an IP address external to the cluster, available to users on your network. When a user logs in, they have access to shared datasets as well as their home directory of personal notebooks, plots, and files.
Further reading: Zero to JupyterHub with Kubernetes.
We do not use Kubernetes today:Installing JupyterHub is even easier! Check out the simple steps here.
Don’t you want to just jump back into your projects when you come back to your computer?

No matter where your experiments and datasets live, it’s possible to eliminate the hassle of constantly redeploying your dev environment. Go do more useful things with your time than spinning up Jupyter over and over.
